#Text=Grdan
#Text=Grdan

#Text=( Serbian Cyrillic : Грдан ; fl. 1596 – d. 1612 ) was the vojvoda ( duke ) of the Nikšić nahija , part of the Sanjak of Herzegovina ( Ottoman Empire ) , who led several uprisings against the Ottomans in between 1596 and 1612 , [ 1 ] alongside Serbian Patriarch Jovan Kantul ( s. 1592 – 1614 ) .
#Text=Life
#Text=Origin
#Text=Grdan was part of the Nikšić tribe . [ 1 ]
#Text=The tribe had originated from Nikša , who was the son of ban Ilijon of Grbalj and maternally a Nemanjić . [ 1 ]
#Text=Nikša had moved to what is now Župa Nikšićka directly after the death of Serbian Emperor Stefan Dušan ( 1355 ) , his relative . [ 1 ]
#Text=From Nikša sprung a powerful tribe , which gave its name to the old župa ( county ) of Onogošt . [ 1 ]
#Text=Nikšić was conquered by the Ottomans and was organized into the Ottoman Sanjak of Herzegovina in the late 15th century .
#Text=Grdan was the vojvoda ( duke ) of the Nikšić nahija . [ 2 ]
#Text=The " vojvoda"-title had been established after conflicts within the tribe as a compromise . [ 3 ]
#Text=Uprising of 1596 – 97
#Text=Main article : Serb Uprising of 1596 – 97
#Text=The Orthodox Christians in the Balkans sought the right moment to revolt against the Ottomans . [ 4 ]
#Text=Serbian , Greek , Bulgarian and Albanian monks visited European courts for help . [ 4 ]

#Text=The crushed Banat Uprising ( 1594 ) had been aided by Serbian Orthodox metropolitans Rufim Njeguš of Cetinje and Visarion of Trebinje ( s. 1590 – 1602 ) . [ 5 ] In 1596 revolts would spread into Ottoman Montenegro and the neighbouring tribes in Herzegovina , especially under influence of Metropolitan Visarion . [ 5 ]
#Text=Visarion and the chieftains in Herzegovina asked the Pope for help . [ 6 ]

#Text=A Ragusan document from the beginning of 1596 claims that many Herzegovinian chieftains with the metropolitan gathered in the Trebinje Monastery where they swore oath " to give up and donate 20,000 heroes to the emperors ' light .

column1: #Text=Jovan assured him that an army of 20,000 , 25 guns and weapons for 25,000 more to be distributed in the Balkans would overwhelm the Ottoman sultan . [ 4 ]
#Text=After years of planning , nothing concrete resulted in it , because such an operation " required Spanish naval and logistical support " . [ 4 ]
#Text=Grdan and Patriarch Jovan continued contact with the successor of Pope Clement , Pope Paul V ( s. 1605 — 1621 ) , with the intention to establish a Christian league against the Ottoman Empire .
#Text=The rebels asked Austria and the Imperial Spanish Kingdom of Naples for aid , in vain .

#Text=In March 1608 , after the assembly at the Kosijerevo monastery , Grdan , the chieftains of Herzegovina and Patriarch Jovan II sent a letter to Spanish king Emanuel I , supporting his liberation plans .
#Text=In April 1608 , at the assembly held at the Morača monastery , the rebels sent a letter to Pope Paul V , encouraging him to influence the Spanish decision to aid them .

#Text=In the next assembly at Morača , held December 13 , 1608 , the chieftains ( of South Herzegovina , Brda , Old Montenegro , Zadrima and Metohija ) proclaimed the Duke of Savoy for their only king and lord .
#Text=However , the Spanish court , having other plans in the West and being threatened by the Republic of Ragusa and the Ottoman Navy , did not want to start a crusade war in the Balkans .
#Text=In 1610 and again in 1612 , Vincenzo Gonzaga , Duke of Mantua sent envoys to Dalmatian coast near Ragusa ( Dubrovnik ) , to meet with Serb and Montenegrin chieftains . [ 4 ]
#Text=Grdan died in 1612 , and he was succeeded as vojvoda of Nikšić by his son Jovan .
#Text=With the death of Grdan ( 1612 ) , and the subsequent imprisonment of Jovan Kantul at Istanbul , Gonzaga never aided in revolt . [ 4 ]
#Text=Aftermath
#Text=After Grdan , the title went to his sons and relatives throughout the 17th century . [ 3 ]
#Text=Nikša 's descendants are the Jovanović brotherhood , a branch of the Nikšić tribe . [ 1 ]
